sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving liquids
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction: 

CH3OH (l) + 3/2 O2 (g) -> CO2 (g) + 2H2O (l) 

given the standard enthalpies of formation for CH3OH (l), CO2 (g) and H2O (l) as -238.6 kJ/mol, -393.5 kJ/mol and -285.8 kJ/mol respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

where ΔH° is the standard enthalpy change, and ΔHf° is the standard enthalpy of formation.

For the given reaction:

CH3OH (l) + 3/2 O2 (g) -> CO2 (g) + 2H2O (l)

The standard enthalpies of formation are:

ΔHf°(CH3OH) = -238.6 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(CO2) = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(H2O) = -285.8 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is:

ΔH° = [1 × (-393.5) + 2 × (-285.8)] - [1 × (-238.6) + 3/2 × 0]

Note that the standard enthalpy of formation for O2 (g) is 0 kJ/mol since it is in its standard state.

ΔH° = [-393.5 - 571.6] - [-238.6]
ΔH° = [-965.1] - [-238.6]
ΔH° = -726.5 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -726.5 kJ/mol.
